resources.string:
GR (Great Hiking): white/red marking; itineraries of several days. GRP (Country GR): yellow/red marking; loops/crossings on a territory scale. • PR (Promenade & Hiking): yellow marking; loops at half day/day.
Makes (forms): • • - = turn left • - = turn right • (or X) = wrong direction (turn back)
To know (very useful in the field): • At the intersections, first look for the brand "good way" ( If you see one, you go in the wrong direction. • Often, a confirmation mark is placed a few dozen meters after the branch line. • If you haven't seen a mark for a while: calmly return to the last safe spot (last mark). • Marks can be on rocks, trunks, poles, walls: sweep to the left/right of the trail and a little higher. • Apart from official routes, local signage can vary: follow the signs on site and remain consistent with the map/trace.
Benchmark: the official markup of GR/GRP/PR is defined by the FFRandonnée.

Before leaving: • Consult a local newsletter + evolution hour by hour (wind, rain, thunderstorms). • Look also: temperature felt in altitude, gusts on peaks, limit rain/snow (if season). • Plan B: shorter/lower route + loops (fast return).
Thunderstorms (simple rules): • Avoid ridges, peaks, edges, clear areas when risk increases. • Remove metal objects (sticks, fences) and move away from isolated trees. • Flash-to-bang: < 30 s between lightning and thunder • Safety position: squat on bag/insulating, feet joints, hands on knees; avoids stretching. • As a group: spread out (10 m) to limit the risk of collective impact. • Wait 30 minutes after the last thunder before you leave.
Other weather traps: • Strong wind: caution on edges/coles (disequilibrium), move away from the edges. • Heavy rain: attention to flash floods (valley bottoms, ravines) + slides. • Fog: slows down, stays grouped, pointing forward (sign, crossing, secondary top).

Before leaving: • Realistically estimate: distance + elevation + duration (margin!), water points, shadow zones, escape. • Download card/trace offline; Check battery + economy mode. • Inform a relative (route + return time): it's simple, it saves.
In the field: • Checks regularly: marking, map, relief (vallon/peak), next marker step. • At intersections: take a break, confirm the direction BEFORE you engage. • Rhythm: regular; micro-pause; drink early (before being thirsty); eat before being drunk.
Group: • The slowest one gives the rhythm. Fixed waiting points. Walking farm. • If someone is tired: shorten/down early (before being at the end).
If you doubt / if you're lost: • STOP: Stop, breathe, observe, find the last safe spot, plan. • Returning to the last safe point is often the best solution (simple and effective). • If weather/night/danger: shelter + heat + battery economy; alert if necessary.

Rule without trace: • Carry all your waste (even biodegradable). Don't leave handkerchiefs. • Natural needs: away from trails and water points; bury (small hole) and plug if possible. • Silence: avoids strong/cris music (fauna + other hikers). Stay quiet near the houses.
Wildlife/herds: • Keep your distance (especially young/wild animals). Don't feed. • Dogs: often forbidden in the heart of the park; elsewhere, leave according to zones/periods (troupeaux, fauna). • If patous: stay calm, bypass widely, do not run, keep the dog close to you (or without leash if necessary to avoid conflict — depending on the situation).
Protected areas: • Stay on the trails (erosion + fragile areas). • Drones: frequently prohibited (especially park hearts) unless authorized.
Altitude lakes: • Often not recommended: fragile ecosystems + pollution (creams) + very cold water (hypothermia) + sometimes prohibited by decree.
Bivouac / Fire: • Bivouac often tolerated 1 night ( remains > 20 m from the lakes/river. • Fires often forbidden: prefers a stove and respects local orders.

Emergency response (France): • 112 (European number) — often operates without a conventional network. • 114 (SMS) if call impossible (also useful if you can't talk). • 15 (SAMU) / 18 (Firemen) / 17 (Police) according to situation.
To say on the phone: • Where? (common/sector, col/refuge/sign, GPS coordinates if possible) • What? (fall, malaise, injury) — how many people — condition (conscious? breathing?) • Possible access (road/track, landmark, on-site weather)
Useful gestures (simple): • Protect – Alert – Help: secure the area first. • Haemorrhage: direct strong compression. • Unconscious who breathes: PLS, cover, monitor. • Tightness/fracture: immobilize, avoid walking, keep warm. • Hypothermia: isolating from the ground, cutting the wind, removing the wet, covering. • Warmness: shadow, refresh, drink in small sips, stop the effort.
Lost / locked in: • Stay together, save the battery, mark your position, shelter, signal yourself (blow/lamp).
